qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: Mostly for calling my daughter who works in Delhi, and sometimes for WhatsApp messages with relatives. I also use it to watch sewing videos on YouTube when my son shows me how.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, I share it with my son and sometimes my husband. My son uses it to help me with apps or watch cricket. My husband uses it to call his brother.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: WhatsApp is my favorite. It helps me stay in touch with my daughter. I also like YouTube because I can see sewing patterns. I don’t really think about what these apps take from my phone.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like access to location or contacts, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No, I don’t understand. I just click ‘yes’, or my son helps me. Sometimes I get scared when too many things pop up.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: If my son installs it or tells me it’s okay, I trust it. I don’t know how to check otherwise.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: Once I deleted a message from a neighbor who kept texting, because I didn’t want any misunderstanding with my husband.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I remove the memory card if I remember. I don’t know how to delete things, so I just give it as it is. I feel worried, but I don’t know how to clean it.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, my son. He helps when something is not working. I feel okay because I trust him, but I don’t like others checking my phone.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I only share personal things face-to-face. I don’t like writing anything private on the phone.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Yes, sometimes I say ‘the sweet one’ when referring to my daughter’s boyfriend, so my husband doesn’t know.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: No, I need to help myself. My son helps me, but I don’t help others.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera or location?
qa.answer: No, I’ve never done that. I didn’t even know it could be done.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I get scared. I ask my son or just close the app.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think they use it to show my photo in the app. I don’t know if they store it.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes. I waited two weeks once because I had personal photos and didn’t know how to delete them.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: A shop guy once looked at my photos and laughed. I felt angry but didn’t say anything because I was scared.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: No, I find it confusing. My son set it once but I forgot it.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I don’t know the difference. I use what my son installs.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: Always my son. He knows everything about phones.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes. My niece once told me not to open strange messages. I follow what they say.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I ask my son to remove some photos, but mostly I leave them as it is because I don’t know how.
scenarios.Sharing a Phone with Family: I ask him to give it back. I sometimes delete messages quickly if I feel uncomfortable.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I ask my son if it’s okay. If he says yes, I say yes.
scenarios.Helping an Elderly Relative: I don’t help, but I ask my son to help them.
scenarios.Using a Borrowed Phone: I pretend I didn’t see anything. It’s not right to look at someone’s things.
scenarios.Selling or Giving Away a Phone: I would take out the SIM and memory card. That’s all I know.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I don’t understand cloud. If it happens, I’d be shocked and ask my son to fix it.
scenarios.Using Free Public WiFi: No, I don’t know how to use public WiFi. My son told me it’s risky.
scenarios.Receiving a lottery: No, I don’t believe them. My niece told me about scams like this.
scenarios.Sharing account details: Only if it’s someone I know well. I don’t do bank things myself—my son does it.
